10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-005-9049-1904910.1007/s10870-005-9049-1ArticleSynthesis and crystal structure of a silver(I) complex with dithioether ligandXieYa-Bo1aLiJian-Rong2BuXian-He2grid.28703.3e0000000090403743Collage of Environmental and Energy EngineeringBeijing University of Technology100022BeijingChinagrid.216938.70000000098787032Department of ChemistryNankai University300071TianjinChinaxieyabo@bjut.edu.cn24120063200636321121512102005862005121020052412006© Springer Science+Business Media, Inc 20062006

The reaction of the dithioether ligand, 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl) quinoxaline (L) with AgBF4, leads to the formation of a novel complex {[AgL](BF4)}∞1, which has been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis: monoclinic, space group C2/c, with a = 20.316(7) Å, b = 12.401(4) Å, c = 18.039(6) Å, β = 108.404(6)° and V = 4312(3) Å3. The crystal structure of the complex consists of 1D {[AgL]+}∞ cation chain and BF4− anions. In 1, the coordination geometry of AgI center can be best described as trigonal planar coordinated by three N from two distinct L ligands. The ligand is polydentate with one end adopting a bidentate conformation to chelate an AgI atom and the other end monodentate to bridge another AgI resulting in an infinite chain along b axis. There exist Ag⋯N weak coordination, π–π stacking and F⋯S weak interactions in the complex, and these weak interactions link the 1D complex into 3D supramolecular structure and further stabilize the crystal structure in the solid state.

KEY WORDS:Crystal structuredithioether ligandsilver(I) complexweak interactionsvolume-issue-count12issue-article-count12issue-toc-levels0issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, Inc.issue-copyright-year2006article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2005article-registration-date-month10article-registration-date-day12article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/10870_2005_Article_9049.pdfoutput-mediumOnlinetarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2006issue-online-date-month8issue-online-date-day4issue-print-date-year2006issue-print-date-month8issue-print-date-day4issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryCrystallography journal-subject-secondaryOrganometallic Chemistry open-accessfalseIntroduction

The suitable organic ligands favoring structure-specific self-assembly are the basis for the construction of coordination architec- tures.1–5 Recently, increasing attention has been paid to the use of flexible bridging units in the construction of supramolecular architectures,6,7 and this approach is attractive because the flexibility and conformation freedoms of such ligands offer the possibility for the construction of unprecedented frameworks with tailored properties and functions.8 In our previous work, the rationally designed dithioether ligands with flexible spacers have been successfully used to construct various structures of complexes including discrete molecules, 1D, 2D, and 3D network architectures.9–12 As a continuation of our series of research on silver(I) coordination compounds with dithioether ligands, a multi-dentate dithioether ligand containing a aromatic spacers, 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl)quinoxaline (L), and a new AgI complex of this ligand, {[AgL](BF4)}∞1, have been synthesized and characterized. We report herein the construction of the novel AgI coordination polymer.

ExperimentalMaterials and general methods

All reagents for synthesis and analyses were of analytical grade and used as received. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on an FT-IR 170SX (Nicolet) spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker AC-P500 spectrometer (300 MHz) at 25°C with tetramethylsilane as the internal reference.

Synthesis of the ligand 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl)quinoxaline (<bold>L</bold>)

The ligand L was prepared according to Scheme 1. 1,4-dibromo-2,3-butanedione was synthesized by the adoption of a literature procedure.13 2,3-bis(bromomethyl)quinoxaline was prepared by the condensation reaction of an equimolar amount of 1,4-dibromo-2,3-butanedione and 1,2-diaminobenzene in ethanol at reflux for ca. 2 h with a yield of 83%. The reaction of 2,3-bis(bromomethyl)quinoxaline with the appropriate 5-methyl-2-sulfanyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole, in the presence of KOH, gaves the ligand 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl)quinoxaline (L) in good yields (84%), and the product was characterized by 1H NMR and elemental analyses. Anal. Found: C, 45.74; H, 3.49; N, 20.28. Calcd. for C16H14N6S4: C, 45.91; H, 3.37; N, 20.08. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 2.72 (s, 6H, –CH3), 5.10 (s, 4H, –SCH2–), 7.73 ∼ 8.07 (m, 4H, Ar–H).

Synthesis of the silver(I) complex {[AgL](BF<sub>4</sub>)}<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

The solution of AgBF4 (0.1 mmol) in CH3CN (3 mL) was slowly added to the solution of L (0.1 mmol) in CHCl3 (3 mL). Slow diffusion of ether into the resulted solution yielded yellow single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis with a yield of 32%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 1698 w, 1633 w, 1569 w, 1489 m, 1427 w, 1402 m, 1210 m, 1063 vs, 777 m, 521 w; analysis calculated for C16H14AgBF4N6S4: C, 31.34; H, 2.30; N, 13.70%; found: C, 31.68; H, 2.43; N, 13.51%.

X-ray crystallographic study of the complex <bold>1</bold>

Single crystal X-ray diffraction was carried out on a Bruker Smart 1000 diffractometer. Intensities of reflections were measured using graphite monochromatized Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with ω-ϕ scan mode at 293(2) K in the range of 2.11 < θ < 26.38°. Unit cell dimensions were obtained with least-squares refinements and semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program.14 The structure was solved by direct method.15 The silver(I) atoms were located from E-maps and the other non-hydrogen atoms were obtained in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinement was performed by full-matrix least-squares methods on F2 by SHELXL-97 program package.16 Hydrogen atoms were included in calculated positions and refined with fixed thermal parameters riding on the parent atoms. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analysis are summarized in Table 1. And selected bond lengths and angles are presented in Table 2. CCDC-274527 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for complex 1. The data can be obtained from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; Fax: +44-1223-336033; E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.

Results and discussion

The flexible dithioether ligand L contains rich structural information in which both the six nitrogen atoms and the four sulfur atoms can act as potential donors to coordinate to metal ions, and the flexible nature of the ligand allows the ligand to bend and rotate when coordinating to metal centers so as to conform to the coordination geometries of metal ions. Multifunctional organic ligands with several potential coordination sites have the ability to interact with their surroundings in addition to their usual function of binding to the transition metal, for instance through weak coordinations or weak interactions, forming supramolecular aggregates. Due to the flexibility and conformational freedom of the ligand L, it is a suitable candidate for investigating the roles of supramolecular interactions and other factors that control the network topologies in the aggregation of coordination architectures. AgI as a soft acid, being inclined to coordinate to soft bases such as S- and unsaturated N-containing ligands, is a favorable and fashionable building block or connecting node for coordination polymers. In our experiment, we attempt to investigate some coordination features of the ligand by the reaction of the dithioether ligand L with AgBF4.

The resulting complex 1 consists of 1D {[AgL]+}∞ cation chain and BF4− anions. In {[AgL]+}∞ cation chain, each AgI center is coordinated by three N atoms from two distinct L ligands (Fig. 1), and the coordination geometry of AgI center can be best described as trigonal planar. Three Ag–N bond lengths of 99.47(10), 108.42(10) and 148.01(10)Å are unequal but fall in the expected ranges for such coordination bonds.17 (Table 2). In addition, the BF4− anions form weak coordination bonds to AgI centers with the Ag⋯F distance of 2.933 Å.

In 1, each ligand uses two N atoms (one from the terminal thiadiazole ring and another from quinoxaline ring) to chelate a AgI atom forming a seven-member ring with chair conformation and an N atom from another terminal thiadiazole ring to bridge another AgI atom resulting in an infinite chain along b axis. The terminal thiadiazole ring providing a bridging N donor is almost in the same plane with the quinoxaline ring, and another thiadiazole ring giving a chelating N donor lies above the quinoxaline plane and incline each other with a dihedral angle of 64.2°. Due to the coordination of an N atom of the quinoxaline ring, the two quinoxaline rings are twisted relative to each other. The silver atom lies above the quinoxaline plane with the upright distance of 0.9886 Å. Only three N atoms of each ligand take part in coordinating to AgI atoms with none S atoms coordinating to AgI atom, indicating the coordination ability of N to AgI atom is stronger than that of S atom. In the chain, the distance of adjacent AgI atoms is ca. 12.401 Å. All quinoxaline rings in the chain are almost in same plane.

An interesting feature of this complex is the formation of Ag⋯N weak interactions between adjacent chains. The Ag⋯N distance of 2.648 Å is significantly shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii of Ag and N (3.27 Å),18 indicating the existence of Ag⋯N weak interactions, and a double-strand chain structure is formed by this weak interactions (Fig. 2). In the double-strand chain, the adjacent quinoxaline and thiadiazole ring are aligned in an off-set fashion, being approximately parallel to each other (the dihedral angle is 15.4°) with the centroid-centroid separation of ca. 3.464 Å, indicating the presence of face-to-face π–π stacking interactions.19 The further investigation of the packing structure found that the distance of F⋯S of 3.044 Å is shorter than the summed van der Waals radii of two atoms (3.27 Å),18 indicating the existence of weak F⋯S interactions between BF4− anions and thiadiazole rings. By these weak F⋯S interactions, the double-strand chains are further stacked along the ac plane forming a 3D supramolecular structure (Fig. 3).

elements.content: The reaction of the dithioether ligand, 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl) quinoxaline (L) with AgBF4, leads to the formation of a novel complex {[AgL](BF4)}∞1, which has been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis: monoclinic, space group C2/c, with a = 20.316(7) Å, b = 12.401(4) Å, c = 18.039(6) Å, β = 108.404(6)° and V = 4312(3) Å3. The crystal structure of the complex consists of 1D {[AgL]+}∞ cation chain and BF4− anions. In 1, the coordination geometry of AgI center can be best described as trigonal planar coordinated by three N from two distinct L ligands. The ligand is polydentate with one end adopting a bidentate conformation to chelate an AgI atom and the other end monodentate to bridge another AgI resulting in an infinite chain along b axis. There exist Ag⋯N weak coordination, π–π stacking and F⋯S weak interactions in the complex, and these weak interactions link the 1D complex into 3D supramolecular structure and further stabilize the crystal structure in the solid state.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of the dithioether ligand, 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl) quinoxaline (L) with AgBF4, leads to the formation of a novel complex {[AgL](BF4)}∞1, which has been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis: monoclinic, space group C2/c, with a = 20.316(7) Å, b = 12.401(4) Å, c = 18.039(6) Å, β = 108.404(6)° and V = 4312(3) Å3. The crystal structure of the complex consists of 1D {[AgL]+}∞ cation chain and BF4- anions. In 1, the coordination geometry of AgI center can be best described as trigonal planar coordinated by three N from two distinct L ligands. The ligand is polydentate with one end adopting a bidentate conformation to chelate an AgI atom and the other end monodentate to bridge another AgI resulting in an infinite chain along b axis. There exist Ag⋯N weak coordination, π-π stacking and F⋯S weak interactions in the complex, and these weak interactions link the 1D complex into 3D supramolecular structure and further stabilize the crystal structure in the solid state.

elements.content: The suitable organic ligands favoring structure-specific self-assembly are the basis for the construction of coordination architec- tures.1–5 Recently, increasing attention has been paid to the use of flexible bridging units in the construction of supramolecular architectures,6,7 and this approach is attractive because the flexibility and conformation freedoms of such ligands offer the possibility for the construction of unprecedented frameworks with tailored properties and functions.8 In our previous work, the rationally designed dithioether ligands with flexible spacers have been successfully used to construct various structures of complexes including discrete molecules, 1D, 2D, and 3D network architectures.9–12 As a continuation of our series of research on silver(I) coordination compounds with dithioether ligands, a multi-dentate dithioether ligand containing a aromatic spacers, 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl)quinoxaline (L), and a new AgI complex of this ligand, {[AgL](BF4)}∞1, have been synthesized and characterized. We report herein the construction of the novel AgI coordination polymer.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The suitable organic ligands favoring structure-specific self-assembly are the basis for the construction of coordination architec- tures.1-5 Recently, increasing attention has been paid to the use of flexible bridging units in the construction of supramolecular architectures,6,7 and this approach is attractive because the flexibility and conformation freedoms of such ligands offer the possibility for the construction of unprecedented frameworks with tailored properties and functions.8 In our previous work, the rationally designed dithioether ligands with flexible spacers have been successfully used to construct various structures of complexes including discrete molecules, 1D, 2D, and 3D network architectures.9-12 As a continuation of our series of research on silver(I) coordination compounds with dithioether ligands, a multi-dentate dithioether ligand containing a aromatic spacers, 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl)quinoxaline (L), and a new AgI complex of this ligand, {[AgL](BF4)}∞1, have been synthesized and characterized. We report herein the construction of the novel AgI coordination polymer.

elements.content: All reagents for synthesis and analyses were of analytical grade and used as received. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on an FT-IR 170SX (Nicolet) spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker AC-P500 spectrometer (300 MHz) at 25°C with tetramethylsilane as the internal reference.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and general methods

All reagents for synthesis and analyses were of analytical grade and used as received. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on an FT-IR 170SX (Nicolet) spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker AC-P500 spectrometer (300 MHz) at 25°C with tetramethylsilane as the internal reference.

elements.content: The ligand L was prepared according to Scheme 1. 1,4-dibromo-2,3-butanedione was synthesized by the adoption of a literature procedure.13 2,3-bis(bromomethyl)quinoxaline was prepared by the condensation reaction of an equimolar amount of 1,4-dibromo-2,3-butanedione and 1,2-diaminobenzene in ethanol at reflux for ca. 2 h with a yield of 83%. The reaction of 2,3-bis(bromomethyl)quinoxaline with the appropriate 5-methyl-2-sulfanyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole, in the presence of KOH, gaves the ligand 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl)quinoxaline (L) in good yields (84%), and the product was characterized by 1H NMR and elemental analyses. Anal. Found: C, 45.74; H, 3.49; N, 20.28. Calcd. for C16H14N6S4: C, 45.91; H, 3.37; N, 20.08. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 2.72 (s, 6H, –CH3), 5.10 (s, 4H, –SCH2–), 7.73 ∼ 8.07 (m, 4H, Ar–H).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the ligand 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl)quinoxaline (L)

The ligand L was prepared according to Scheme 1. 1,4-dibromo-2,3-butanedione was synthesized by the adoption of a literature procedure.13 2,3-bis(bromomethyl)quinoxaline was prepared by the condensation reaction of an equimolar amount of 1,4-dibromo-2,3-butanedione and 1,2-diaminobenzene in ethanol at reflux for ca. 2 h with a yield of 83%. The reaction of 2,3-bis(bromomethyl)quinoxaline with the appropriate 5-methyl-2-sulfanyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole, in the presence of KOH, gaves the ligand 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl)quinoxaline (L) in good yields (84%), and the product was characterized by 1H NMR and elemental analyses. Anal. Found: C, 45.74; H, 3.49; N, 20.28. Calcd. for C16H14N6S4: C, 45.91; H, 3.37; N, 20.08. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 2.72 (s, 6H, -CH3), 5.10 (s, 4H, -SCH2-), 7.73 ~ 8.07 (m, 4H, Ar-H).

elements.content: The solution of AgBF4 (0.1 mmol) in CH3CN (3 mL) was slowly added to the solution of L (0.1 mmol) in CHCl3 (3 mL). Slow diffusion of ether into the resulted solution yielded yellow single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis with a yield of 32%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 1698 w, 1633 w, 1569 w, 1489 m, 1427 w, 1402 m, 1210 m, 1063 vs, 777 m, 521 w; analysis calculated for C16H14AgBF4N6S4: C, 31.34; H, 2.30; N, 13.70%; found: C, 31.68; H, 2.43; N, 13.51%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the silver(I) complex {[AgL](BF4)}∞ (1)

The solution of AgBF4 (0.1 mmol) in CH3CN (3 mL) was slowly added to the solution of L (0.1 mmol) in CHCl3 (3 mL). Slow diffusion of ether into the resulted solution yielded yellow single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis with a yield of 32%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1698 w, 1633 w, 1569 w, 1489 m, 1427 w, 1402 m, 1210 m, 1063 vs, 777 m, 521 w; analysis calculated for C16H14AgBF4N6S4: C, 31.34; H, 2.30; N, 13.70%; found: C, 31.68; H, 2.43; N, 13.51%.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction was carried out on a Bruker Smart 1000 diffractometer. Intensities of reflections were measured using graphite monochromatized Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with ω-ϕ scan mode at 293(2) K in the range of 2.11 < θ < 26.38°. Unit cell dimensions were obtained with least-squares refinements and semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program.14 The structure was solved by direct method.15 The silver(I) atoms were located from E-maps and the other non-hydrogen atoms were obtained in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinement was performed by full-matrix least-squares methods on F2 by SHELXL-97 program package.16 Hydrogen atoms were included in calculated positions and refined with fixed thermal parameters riding on the parent atoms. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analysis are summarized in Table 1. And selected bond lengths and angles are presented in Table 2. CCDC-274527 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for complex 1. The data can be obtained from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; Fax: +44-1223-336033; E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic study of the complex 1

Single crystal X-ray diffraction was carried out on a Bruker Smart 1000 diffractometer. Intensities of reflections were measured using graphite monochromatized Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with ω-ϕ scan mode at 293(2) K in the range of 2.11 <  θ  < 26.38°. Unit cell dimensions were obtained with least-squares refinements and semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program.14 The structure was solved by direct method.15 The silver(I) atoms were located from E-maps and the other non-hydrogen atoms were obtained in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinement was performed by full-matrix least-squares methods on F2 by SHELXL-97 program package.16 Hydrogen atoms were included in calculated positions and refined with fixed thermal parameters riding on the parent atoms. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analysis are summarized in Table 1. And selected bond lengths and angles are presented in Table 2. CCDC-274527 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for complex 1. The data can be obtained from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; Fax: +44-1223-336033; E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.

Symmetry code: x, y−1, z.

The flexible dithioether ligand L contains rich structural information in which both the six nitrogen atoms and the four sulfur atoms can act as potential donors to coordinate to metal ions, and the flexible nature of the ligand allows the ligand to bend and rotate when coordinating to metal centers so as to conform to the coordination geometries of metal ions. Multifunctional organic ligands with several potential coordination sites have the ability to interact with their surroundings in addition to their usual function of binding to the transition metal, for instance through weak coordinations or weak interactions, forming supramolecular aggregates. Due to the flexibility and conformational freedom of the ligand L, it is a suitable candidate for investigating the roles of supramolecular interactions and other factors that control the network topologies in the aggregation of coordination architectures. AgI as a soft acid, being inclined to coordinate to soft bases such as S- and unsaturated N-containing ligands, is a favorable and fashionable building block or connecting node for coordination polymers. In our experiment, we attempt to investigate some coordination features of the ligand by the reaction of the dithioether ligand L with AgBF4.
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The flexible dithioether ligand L contains rich structural information in which both the six nitrogen atoms and the four sulfur atoms can act as potential donors to coordinate to metal ions, and the flexible nature of the ligand allows the ligand to bend and rotate when coordinating to metal centers so as to conform to the coordination geometries of metal ions. Multifunctional organic ligands with several potential coordination sites have the ability to interact with their surroundings in addition to their usual function of binding to the transition metal, for instance through weak coordinations or weak interactions, forming supramolecular aggregates. Due to the flexibility and conformational freedom of the ligand L, it is a suitable candidate for investigating the roles of supramolecular interactions and other factors that control the network topologies in the aggregation of coordination architectures. AgI as a soft acid, being inclined to coordinate to soft bases such as S- and unsaturated N-containing ligands, is a favorable and fashionable building block or connecting node for coordination polymers. In our experiment, we attempt to investigate some coordination features of the ligand by the reaction of the dithioether ligand L with AgBF4.

elements.content: The resulting complex 1 consists of 1D {[AgL]+}∞ cation chain and BF4− anions. In {[AgL]+}∞ cation chain, each AgI center is coordinated by three N atoms from two distinct L ligands (Fig. 1), and the coordination geometry of AgI center can be best described as trigonal planar. Three Ag–N bond lengths of 99.47(10), 108.42(10) and 148.01(10)Å are unequal but fall in the expected ranges for such coordination bonds.17 (Table 2). In addition, the BF4− anions form weak coordination bonds to AgI centers with the Ag⋯F distance of 2.933 Å.
elements.clean_text: The resulting complex 1 consists of 1D {[AgL]+}∞ cation chain and BF4- anions. In {[AgL]+}∞ cation chain, each AgI center is coordinated by three N atoms from two distinct L ligands (Fig. 1), and the coordination geometry of AgI center can be best described as trigonal planar. Three Ag-N bond lengths of 99.47(10), 108.42(10) and 148.01(10)Å are unequal but fall in the expected ranges for such coordination bonds.17 (Table 2). In addition, the BF4- anions form weak coordination bonds to AgI centers with the Ag⋯F distance of 2.933 Å.

elements.content: ORTEP view with atom labeling (displacement ellipsoids drawn at 30% probability) of the structure of complex 1.
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1.ORTEP view with atom labeling (displacement ellipsoids drawn at 30% probability) of the structure of complex 1.

elements.content: The double-strand chain of 1 formed by the Ag⋯N weak coordination.
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2.The double-strand chain of 1 formed by the Ag⋯N weak coordination.

elements.content: In 1, each ligand uses two N atoms (one from the terminal thiadiazole ring and another from quinoxaline ring) to chelate a AgI atom forming a seven-member ring with chair conformation and an N atom from another terminal thiadiazole ring to bridge another AgI atom resulting in an infinite chain along b axis. The terminal thiadiazole ring providing a bridging N donor is almost in the same plane with the quinoxaline ring, and another thiadiazole ring giving a chelating N donor lies above the quinoxaline plane and incline each other with a dihedral angle of 64.2°. Due to the coordination of an N atom of the quinoxaline ring, the two quinoxaline rings are twisted relative to each other. The silver atom lies above the quinoxaline plane with the upright distance of 0.9886 Å. Only three N atoms of each ligand take part in coordinating to AgI atoms with none S atoms coordinating to AgI atom, indicating the coordination ability of N to AgI atom is stronger than that of S atom. In the chain, the distance of adjacent AgI atoms is ca. 12.401 Å. All quinoxaline rings in the chain are almost in same plane.
elements.clean_text: In 1, each ligand uses two N atoms (one from the terminal thiadiazole ring and another from quinoxaline ring) to chelate a AgI atom forming a seven-member ring with chair conformation and an N atom from another terminal thiadiazole ring to bridge another AgI atom resulting in an infinite chain along b axis. The terminal thiadiazole ring providing a bridging N donor is almost in the same plane with the quinoxaline ring, and another thiadiazole ring giving a chelating N donor lies above the quinoxaline plane and incline each other with a dihedral angle of 64.2°. Due to the coordination of an N atom of the quinoxaline ring, the two quinoxaline rings are twisted relative to each other. The silver atom lies above the quinoxaline plane with the upright distance of 0.9886 Å. Only three N atoms of each ligand take part in coordinating to AgI atoms with none S atoms coordinating to AgI atom, indicating the coordination ability of N to AgI atom is stronger than that of S atom. In the chain, the distance of adjacent AgI atoms is ca. 12.401 Å. All quinoxaline rings in the chain are almost in same plane.

elements.content: An interesting feature of this complex is the formation of Ag⋯N weak interactions between adjacent chains. The Ag⋯N distance of 2.648 Å is significantly shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii of Ag and N (3.27 Å),18 indicating the existence of Ag⋯N weak interactions, and a double-strand chain structure is formed by this weak interactions (Fig. 2). In the double-strand chain, the adjacent quinoxaline and thiadiazole ring are aligned in an off-set fashion, being approximately parallel to each other (the dihedral angle is 15.4°) with the centroid-centroid separation of ca. 3.464 Å, indicating the presence of face-to-face π–π stacking interactions.19 The further investigation of the packing structure found that the distance of F⋯S of 3.044 Å is shorter than the summed van der Waals radii of two atoms (3.27 Å),18 indicating the existence of weak F⋯S interactions between BF4− anions and thiadiazole rings. By these weak F⋯S interactions, the double-strand chains are further stacked along the ac plane forming a 3D supramolecular structure (Fig. 3).
elements.clean_text: An interesting feature of this complex is the formation of Ag⋯N weak interactions between adjacent chains. The Ag⋯N distance of 2.648 Å is significantly shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii of Ag and N (3.27 Å),18 indicating the existence of Ag⋯N weak interactions, and a double-strand chain structure is formed by this weak interactions (Fig. 2). In the double-strand chain, the adjacent quinoxaline and thiadiazole ring are aligned in an off-set fashion, being approximately parallel to each other (the dihedral angle is 15.4°) with the centroid-centroid separation of ca. 3.464 Å, indicating the presence of face-to-face π-π stacking interactions.19 The further investigation of the packing structure found that the distance of F⋯S of 3.044 Å is shorter than the summed van der Waals radii of two atoms (3.27 Å),18 indicating the existence of weak F⋯S interactions between BF4- anions and thiadiazole rings. By these weak F⋯S interactions, the double-strand chains are further stacked along the ac plane forming a 3D supramolecular structure (Fig. 3).

elements.content: The 3D supramolecular structure formed through the weak F⋯S interactions.
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3.The 3D supramolecular structure formed through the weak F⋯S interactions.

cln_elements.content:
The ligand L was prepared according to Scheme 1. 1,4-dibromo-2,3-butanedione was synthesized by the adoption of a literature procedure.13 2,3-bis(bromomethyl)quinoxaline was prepared by the condensation reaction of an equimolar amount of 1,4-dibromo-2,3-butanedione and 1,2-diaminobenzene in ethanol at reflux for ca. 2 h with a yield of 83%. The reaction of 2,3-bis(bromomethyl)quinoxaline with the appropriate 5-methyl-2-sulfanyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole, in the presence of KOH, gaves the ligand 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl)quinoxaline (L) in good yields (84%), and the product was characterized by 1H NMR and elemental analyses. Anal. Found: C, 45.74; H, 3.49; N, 20.28. Calcd. for C16H14N6S4: C, 45.91; H, 3.37; N, 20.08. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 2.72 (s, 6H, –CH3), 5.10 (s, 4H, –SCH2–), 7.73 ∼ 8.07 (m, 4H, Ar–H).

Synthesis of the silver(I) complex {[AgL](BF<sub>4</sub>)}<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

The solution of AgBF4 (0.1 mmol) in CH3CN (3 mL) was slowly added to the solution of L (0.1 mmol) in CHCl3 (3 mL). Slow diffusion of ether into the resulted solution yielded yellow single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis with a yield of 32%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 1698 w, 1633 w, 1569 w, 1489 m, 1427 w, 1402 m, 1210 m, 1063 vs, 777 m, 521 w; analysis calculated for C16H14AgBF4N6S4: C, 31.34; H, 2.30; N, 13.70%; found: C, 31.68; H, 2.43; N, 13.51%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the ligand 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl)quinoxaline (L)

The ligand L was prepared according to Scheme 1. 1,4-dibromo-2,3-butanedione was synthesized by the adoption of a literature procedure.13 2,3-bis(bromomethyl)quinoxaline was prepared by the condensation reaction of an equimolar amount of 1,4-dibromo-2,3-butanedione and 1,2-diaminobenzene in ethanol at reflux for ca. 2 h with a yield of 83%. The reaction of 2,3-bis(bromomethyl)quinoxaline with the appropriate 5-methyl-2-sulfanyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole, in the presence of KOH, gaves the ligand 2,3-bis(5-methyl-1,3,4-thiadiazole-2-thiomethyl)quinoxaline (L) in good yields (84%), and the product was characterized by 1H NMR and elemental analyses. Anal. Found: C, 45.74; H, 3.49; N, 20.28. Calcd. for C16H14N6S4: C, 45.91; H, 3.37; N, 20.08. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 2.72 (s, 6H, -CH3), 5.10 (s, 4H, -SCH2-), 7.73 ~ 8.07 (m, 4H, Ar-H).

Synthesis of the silver(I) complex {[AgL](BF4)}∞ (1)

The solution of AgBF4 (0.1 mmol) in CH3CN (3 mL) was slowly added to the solution of L (0.1 mmol) in CHCl3 (3 mL). Slow diffusion of ether into the resulted solution yielded yellow single crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray analysis with a yield of 32%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1698 w, 1633 w, 1569 w, 1489 m, 1427 w, 1402 m, 1210 m, 1063 vs, 777 m, 521 w; analysis calculated for C16H14AgBF4N6S4: C, 31.34; H, 2.30; N, 13.70%; found: C, 31.68; H, 2.43; N, 13.51%.

The crystal structure of the complex consists of 1D {[AgL]+}∞ cation chain and BF4− anions. In 1, the coordination geometry of AgI center can be best described as trigonal planar coordinated by three N from two distinct L ligands. The ligand is polydentate with one end adopting a bidentate conformation to chelate an AgI atom and the other end monodentate to bridge another AgI resulting in an infinite chain along b axis. There exist Ag⋯N weak coordination, π–π stacking and F⋯S weak interactions in the complex, and these weak interactions link the 1D complex into 3D supramolecular structure and further stabilize the crystal structure in the solid state.
